title: PSA: If you're feeding, don't build straight damage
body:
And feed more. I can't think of anything off the top of my head that angers me more than someone giving up a couple early kills to someone, then not modifying their game plan one bit. They continue pushing (without wards), fighting their fed and ahead lane opponent, and building straight damage. Then, when they continue to get kills, you hear cries of "OP" or "broken."

Like last match. Our Darius fed Illaoi to the point that he was a lost cause very early on. Then our Rengar kept ganking her, rather than helping our bot lane, or me mid, when we had an ADC with connection issues. At one point, our Brand support went up with him when I was trying to defend a turret by myself versus Swain and Lux. They all ended up dying, which is no surprise considering Illaoi's damage only goes up when there are more people around.

But all I heard was how broken and OP she is. When I pointed out her awful win rate (43.7% ATM), one of my teammates said people that have played her 15-50 times have an 80% win rate with them. I just looked it up, and it's 76.44%... and that's 0.44% of her playerbase. AKA, it doesn't mean a damned thing because the sample size is way too small.

She's too new to really make any value judgments yet. I'll admit her E is a bit too powerful, and that I'm not a fan of her tentacles spawning at your turret (and not being targeted by said turret) if she's bullied you up to it... but overall, she's by no means "broken," at least not in my opinion. People don't know how to play against or as her yet, so all her stats are a bit of a crapshoot right now. And neither the stats for 0.44% of her playerbase, nor a match where you played right into her hand the entire time, is proof of anything.

Except I see this all the time, where people are incapable of adjusting in-match, or of viewing what happens in that match in context. I've had numerous matches where I couldn't even be in sight of my lane opponent without getting killed in seconds because they'd gotten that far ahead, but I managed to find ways to not just let them pile up kills and to at least slow the bleeding. Very few people in this game seem to know how to do that, however, and it drives me mad.

Well, of course. But even ADCs have ways to build semi-defensively while still getting the damage they're after. Well, it's pretty much limited to lifesteal, but still. It's something.

In fact, everyone has options that give them both offensive and defensive stats. For example, I was {{champion:117}} top vs. {{champion:17}} last match. What most randoms I see would  probably do in that situation is go for something like a {{item:3089}}, which is pricey and straight damage.

What elo do they build a deathcap as one of their first items? Generally you see people building some sort of mana regen, like Morellonomicon, or a defensive ap item, like Zhonyas. If not that, the most agressive players go for ludens

I'm not saying I literally have seen people do that exact thing. Was using Deathcap as an example of a straight damage item someone might buy over something like Abyssal. The exact item doesn't matter. My point is, I've played with and against tons of players gold and below who don't seem to understand that damage doesn't help you when the enemy Lulu can halve your health with a single Q (like I did to the Nid in my last match with no defensive items).

ahhhhh

{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}}

It's actually reversed, if you are ahead you build defensive items, if you are behind you go offense. That's the reason fed ADCs get GA/Banshees far earlier than when they are not fed.

For example, i play Vel'Koz mid into Brand. 
If i get 0/2, i build MORE damage, because i can't face him in the open, so my chance is to catch him off-guard. If i do that i want to punish him hard and completely destroy him with single combo if possible. If i built defensive item, i wouldn't have enough damage to burst him down and he could kill me despite me having defensive item.
Now, if i get ahead, let's say 3/0, i build big defensive item. If he tries to go toe to toe with me he'll just die because he's behind, and if i make a mistake/get jumped on i have far better chance for surviving and fighting back.

If Zed can easily kill me without even using his R, why would i even bother to get zhonya's? Instead, i can get few good wards, catch him with CC and nuke him down before he has chance to retaliate.

But there's the difference: you apparently know how to modify your play style when behind. As I said in the first paragraph of the OP, I'm talking about the people who start 0/2, rush some expensive damage item, die a couple more times because they keep making stupid mistakes (i.e., pushing too hard, not warding, trying to pick fights, etc.), and continue to feed until things are so out of hand that (at best) it takes our entire team to kill the monster he created.

I'm talking about situations where they can barely be in the same lane as their opponent and yet they do nothing to itemize against it. I've been in situations myself where that's the case, and building at least somewhat defensively is sometimes the only way you can prevent the snowball, which is huge in a meta that's based almost entirely around snowballing at this point.

To put it more succinctly, I love when my lane opponent builds offensively when I'm ahead and fed.

It's why, back when I played almost nothing but Garen, Teemo was by far my favorite lane opponent. Like clockwork, they'd all build AP, while I played safe until I had some levels and MR and could kill their squishy selves before they had a chance to use all that damage.
